content: P.L. 106-554, signed in December 2000, enacted the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government Appropriations, 2001. It provided funding for various accounts, including the General Services Administration for transition administration and the Executive Residence for White House family transfers. P.L. 106-346 (H.R. 4475) partially funded select accounts from the primary funding measure. Various measures were considered before the enactment of P.L. 106-554 for funding affected accounts. Before the enactment of P.L. 106-554, various measures were considered to fund affected accounts, including House bill H.R. 4871, Senate bill S. 2900, Legislative Branch Appropriation H.R. 4516/H.R. 4985, Transportation Appropriations P.L. 106-346, FY2001 Continuing Funding Resolution P.L. 106-275, and others. The bulk of the accounts within the Treasury, Postal Service, Executive Office of the President, and General Government FY2001 were funded through P.L. 106-554. The Act P.L. 106-554 (H.R. 4577/H.R. 5658) authorizes the use of White House funds for transition moving expenses. P.L. 106-346 provides supplemental funding for certain accounts. The President submits the Budget of the United States Government annually. Congress passes a concurrent resolution establishing the congressional budget and allocates discretionary funding levels to subcommittees. See "Major Funding Trends" for FY2001 allocations for Treasury and General Government appropriations. The House and Senate Appropriations Committees allocate discretionary funding levels to subcommittees for various departments, including the Department of the Treasury. This funding covers law enforcement organizations, the U.S. Postal Service, and the Executive Office of the President. The U.S. Postal Service is mostly self-supporting, with federal contributions limited to compensating for foregone revenues. Appropriations for the Executive Office of the President cover salaries, expenses, and operations of various agencies. Independent agencies funded through this appropriation include the Federal Election Commission, General Services Administration, and others. The Treasury and General Government appropriation includes funding for specific agencies and additional titles. The Treasury and General Government appropriation includes funding for various agencies such as the Federal Election Commission, General Services Administration, and others. It also contains general titles that set governmentwide restrictions and authorize specific actions, such as prohibiting the use of funds for non-U.S. citizens' employment and authorizing travel expenses for federal employees' immediate family members in certain situations. New provisions in titles V and VI are presented as part of the Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001. The Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2001 includes a .22% across-the-board rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations funds affecting all accounts in the Treasury and General Government appropriations. The Office of Management and Budget is required to report on the implementation of the rescission when the FY2002 budget is submitted. Advance appropriations for FY 2001 provided in FY 2000 or earlier years are subject to the rescission, while advance appropriations for FY 2001 provided in FY 2001 appropriations acts for FY 2002 and future years are not affected. The rescission of FY2001 discretionary budget authority and obligation limitations applies to all agencies. It includes a 0.22% reduction that must be equally applied to each program, project, and activity. Mandatory PPA and transfers of mandatory funds to discretionary PPA are exempt from the rescission. Agencies will receive specific instructions on the required actions. The FY 2001 President's budget specifies a 0.22% rescission for discretionary PPA, with no flexibility in allocation. Agencies must apply the reduction equally to all programs, projects, and activities subject to the rescission. The FY2000 Consolidated Appropriations Act also included a 0.38% across-the-board rescission. The FY2001 budget included a 0.38% across-the-board rescission, with departments required to achieve the savings while allowing flexibility to protect high-priority programs. Certain programs were exempt, but the rescission was to be universally applied. The FY2001 Military Construction Appropriations Act affected some accounts covered by the Treasury/Postal Service measure. The Treasury/Postal Service measure impacts accounts by reverting pay dates for federal civilian personnel to FY2000, altering funding levels.
